body: rebased/merged
Store only one version of the components, namely the "resolved" ones as FQEN (FullyQualifiedEntityName), get rid of strings.

You could pass that explicitly as part of the feed creation? (As a workaround.)

`wsk trigger create T --feed F --param endpoint xxx.yyy.zzz`

This is related to https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/issues/616, https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/issues/218 and https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/issues/387. We should add the endpoint to the context available to all the runtimes.

Hi @ddragosd Are you aware that we have VM approach to setup OpenWhisk locally with no more requirement than having virtual box and vagrant installed?

Why is this not good option for you?

If you don't want to use a VM and want to run locally on your mac or linux you can use ansible, using ansible helps us have a good story around CICD for devops, what contributors are using their local environment matches and very close to what we use to build, deploy in production.

In the past we were using ant and gradle to do the build and deploy, then we re-engineer the whole process to use gradle only for building and ansible for deploying.

We moved into ansible to help us with our CI/CD and be able to maintained all variables and configuration in a single place under ansible, and have overrrides per environments

What are the problems you are facing with ansible?

thanks for the feedback @csantanapr .

I think the first problem is downgrading my docker version which I prefer to avoid if possible. I tried to work around it by using `ansible/environments/local` then I got stuck at a python library to manage docker ( IIRC `docker-py` was having issues )

The second aspect (not a direct issue for me) is enforcing a deployment technology on everyone unless it's really needed. I do appreciate the idea of consistency and I personally like it a lot, but I'm not sure how aligned is with other devops teams . 

A docker-compose approach may  also be used for integration tests between components. I find myself using this quite often in a microservices environment.  I did not dig too much into the code to see how is this handled currently.

Forgive my ignorance - below is my first `go` program. If we read a JSON object and then can separate the key and value pairs, I don't see why the mapping can't happen entirely in the CLI for now.

```
package main

import "encoding/json"
import "fmt"

func main() {
    bytes := []byte(`{"a":"A","b":["B","C"]}`)
    var data map[string]interface{}
    if err := json.Unmarshal(bytes, &data); err != nil {
        panic(err)
    }
    fmt.Println(data)

    keys := make([]string, len(data))
    values := make([]interface{}, len(data))

    i := 0
    for k, v := range data {
       keys[i] = k
       values[i] = v
       i++
    }

    fmt.Println(keys)
    fmt.Println(values)
}
```

```
> go run main.go 
map[a:A b:[B C]]
[a b]
[A [B C]]
```

Also note that when invoking an action, the API expects the POST content to be a JSON object - in which case you don't need to serialize the object at all. What I suggested above is only necessary for action create/update where the parameters are stored in the action record in the format [{"key", "value"}].
@rabbah, yes I was able to achieve the above. From here we need to add the key/value labels, then encode the JSON back into a struct.

:) re: workaround
yep using this currently...

```
wsk trigger create myT -f myF -p endpoint `wsk property get --apihost | awk -F"([ ][ ]+)|(\t+)" '{print $2}'`
```

or the package variant

```
wsk package create myP -p endpoint `wsk property get --apihost | awk -F"([ ][ ]+)|(\t+)" '{print $2}'`
```

... for anyone else who is doing this sort of thing in an install script

First of all, thanks a lot for your contribution. Feedback on our deployment technologies is always very appreciated we're looking to make it as easy as possible for ourselves aswell. 

Two thoughts to docker-compose and your comments:
1. We've been on docker 1.9 for a reason. It's not because the deployment otherwise doesn't work, but we had issues with docker 1.10 and 1.11 in our production systems, which seem to be resolved with 1.12, which is why we're currently in the progress of migrating to it. Hopefully we'll be able to give green light to update all developer setups as well.
2. We've also looked at docker-compose as a deployment tool (actually, I personally did the prototypes for docker-compose, ansible, chef etc.). I found that ansible is basically a superset of docker-compose (it really is with the newest version of the docker module) with a bit more flexibility when it comes to setting up VMs the way we want it, copying files around etc. All in all: The decision was deliberate.

Feedback as I said is of course always welcome and I'm happy to give feedback on the docker-compose version of our deployment.

thanks @markusthoemmes. 

Given that right now I can't make much progress with Docker 1.12 do you happen to have something that would help me progress faster with `docker-compose` instead ? 

I'm not trying to make this issue a debate on ansible. I think that however we do it, if we can provide a 1 liner simple command such as `make quick-start` and _it works_ it would be of great help.  

I hope I'm not sending the wrong message; I have nothing against ansible, I'd just love to have a much easier setup for local development.

Large organizations tend to standardize deployment technologies if that's Ansible they're in luck, but otherwise, it's unlikely they'll switch to or mix-in Ansible. Likely these will become available as external projects. 

Having multiple options within the project is convenient for users but places a burden on the project maintainers :)

Kubernetes for example chose to keep them internally https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/tree/master/cluster

As for Vagrant vs Docker https://circleci.com/blog/its-the-future/ ;)
@rabbah good to go?

@domdom82 thanks for the quick answer.

My two cents are that we should upgrade to 1.12 for the client, most people trying to use this repo are not using our internal system from their local dev setup.
Beautiful Green Travis - @rabbah ready for a second round of comments. I think I fixed everything from the first round. Once I fix everything, I'll squash in one commit.

> if we can provide a 1 liner simple command such as make quick-start 

@ddragosd  We do offer `wskdev fresh` where `wskdev` hides the underlying `gradle` and `ansible` tools used to build and deploy; for most local development, it's sufficient and convenient to work with `wskdev` (see https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/tree/master/tools/build#how-to-use-redo, which is aliased to `wskdev`). I use this exclusively with docker-machine on a macbook.

As for whether this "works" - if you're having trouble with gradle and ansible, then using `wskdev` will have the same trouble since it's just a wrapper around these.

I agree with @clehene's point that "having multiple options within the project is convenient for users but places a burden on the project maintainers" - if we don't test it, it will break (so putting additional options outside the main repo has the advantage of shifting the burden elsewhere).

Last patch resolved restart of couchdb.

Merged as https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/commit/bd12935a71eabce39ca39fcf60e0006836bd2f63.

Taking new stock of some candidate bits that we can move out of the main repo:
1. mobile starter app
2. ansible files for distributed deployments
3. reconsider the cli (requires that we boost our API based testing)
4. python sdk (formerly the cli)
5. some/all of the language runtimes (#1316)
6. docker sdk
7. docs (as noted already)

I think we should reconsider this:
1. cut down build time - the CLI now is much more convenient to view as a binary we can install (pin a version we need)
2. we need to boost our API based testing which the CLI system tests allow us to continue to cheat on
3. allows others to work on the CLI independent of the main repo (ie if I only want to develop the CLI, I don't need the overhead of the rest of the system)

Is there a way to add multiple travis builds in a pipeline kind of way?
I am wondering because there is (besides the number of runtimes) in general the natural problem of ever increasing number of tests which will by definition at some point hit a time limit that is unacceptable.

We are currently executing the majority of tests in one huge suite in `:tests:test` which is also a nuisance if you want to e.g. update just documentation (which should also be tested btw.)

So if we were able to split those into smaller but faster pieces - for example with a pluggable runtime, but not necessarily stop there - be awesome. 

If that does not work, my only other idea would be to split into multiple repos and assign one travis build for each repo and have them pick up each other.
@markusthoemmes duplicate of https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/issues/319? If you agree consolidate and close one.

This becomes more important as we're constantly hitting CI/CD build time limits and increase our feedback time as we add more and more runtimes. Also impacts local deployments, especially first-time users with a long installation time.
Agreeing, commented under your issue. Closing.

Either [GitHub Releases](https://help.github.com/articles/about-releases/) or [Bintray](https://bintray.com/) are good candidates for hosting binaries of open-source projects.

The `openwhisk/cli` project could post platform- and version- specific compiled artifacts there, which the others build would fetch based on the pinned information.

@rabbah Your suggesting that we start creating a go cli binary with a semantic version?
With the current v1 of the API we can start with a 1.0.0, when v2 of the whisk api starts showing up we can have version 2.0.0 of the API.

We can use git tags for version and releases,
Use git branches 1.x, or 1.1.x 2.x, 2.2.x for release and version management

This will be another benefit of having it's own repo, but more work to maintained. So we need to agree to invest to build the automation and infrastructure to releases

@psuter I never heard of Bintray
I would say to start lets use Github releases and keep it in one place
I've generally done for pairs of properties for convenience. For a singleton, we have generally referenced it by name in the map for the required properties.

String interpolation does not work when creating strings surrounded by single quotes in a shell script. That means we will have to use double quotes to create strings, and escape double quotes inside those strings.

The CLI version, build, and date are not included in the JSON file yet. Those entries will be added in a different PR. When we include that information it should be consistent with what is shown in `wsk property get`.

In general, it looks fine, however I would like to avoid using the external scripts, the scripts read properties again in whisk.properties which are again generated from ansible envs. Here Ansible does not do much magic except calling those scripts. Can we move the cli calls in scripts to ansible task/playbooks. It's easier to manage.

@lehoanganh - Good point.  I did not think all all whisk.properties values were exactly available as ansible environment variables.  For example, the db.whisk.actions whisk.properties value has no exact ansible equivalent.  Same for db.whisk.gwapi.  whisk.properties.j2 template file has some hardcoded strings that ansible does not have and I was reluctant to include the same hardcoded string values in a second place.

Thanks for the feedback. 

The first thing I'll try to do is get rid of the components field and use instead the new class we have so we always store FQEN for components. I think this is the way to go, we shouldn't have used Strings to begin with. This involves messing around with @perryibm 's code (for sequences with pipe.js), I hope I'll iron out the differences so I can still have both versions of the code in place. 

This is done as of 70518b5.
Current parameters for sequences are overwritten by the names of the components. Fix this!
you have rights :).
Also: you may want to write something like `Fixes #1133` explicitly in the commit message to make GitHub dark magic work: https://help.github.com/articles/closing-issues-via-commit-messages/

Notes from discussion with @psuter today:

It might be going too far to define the empty object {} as an abort condition for sequences, since it's easy to imagine lots of actions that run correctly with empty inputs.   This is especially true when you consider that we can specify default values for parameters.

Philippe reminded me that we already have a convention that if the return object contains a field called "error", we have a convention that this indicates erroneous completion and terminates the sequence.

Perhaps it would be better to use this kind of convention.   For example, perhaps we could further adopt the convention that if the value of "error" is `null`, then it aborts the sequence, but for the purposes of logging, this is not considered a real error.   Alternatively we could reserve another keyword (abort?  exit? stop?) ... however maybe we should avoid reserving more keywords since each such keyword increases the chances that someone uses the keyword by accident.

~~It turns out the two tests for sequences and parameters in ActionsApiTests are broken. The initial sequence action is never installed in the db. I'm ignoring these tests for now and fixing once I have the implementation for sequence all in.~~

That's not correct. The tests are not broken, they are sneaky. They do not install the sequence action by calling the api, instead they install the action directly in the db, so the checks that would happen during creation through the api are skipped. Fixing the tests now.
